awd_titl_txt: LEAP-HI: Ultra-Low Power Computing: A Disruptive Approach Through a New Integrated Nanomechanics Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern society relies on microelectronic computing devices.  Performing billions of calculations per second, microprocessors enable the internet, smart phones, laptop computers, cloud computing and digital cameras. Although microprocessors are extremely powerful when it comes to fast computation, they consume a lot of energy.  This is because the billions of transistors in microprocessors have become so small that they leak electrical current even when they are off.  New generations of powerful computing hardware will require more energy efficient microprocessors.  Transistors are solid state switches with no moving parts.  This Leading Engineering for America's Prosperity, Health, and Infrastructure (LEAP-HI) award supports fundamental research to replace solid state transistors with nanomechanical switches that can open and close to make and break an electrical contact.  These contacts can operate at the speed of computers because of their incredibly small size.
  
Nanomechanical switch contacts are operated with nanonewton forces applied normal to the interface.  Though small, the actual points of contact - nanometer-scale asperities - are subject to both high stress and high current density, creating multiple degradation pathways.  Metallic materials have been used to make the electrical contacts, but they eventually weld together. The objective of this work is to investigate whether hard conducting oxide coatings on the metals can be used to overcome this adhesion problem. The intellectual merit of this project is in meeting a grand challenge at the intersection of mechanics, tribology and materials development: to develop interfacial systems that not only achieve but maintain extremely low and stable adhesion and electrical contact resistance after billions to trillions of contact cycles with minimal degradation.  To accomplish this, the research team will perform density functional theory calculations of oxide conduction mechanisms, and finite element and molecular dynamics modeling of contact stresses.  Experimentally, different oxides will be tested using atomic force microscopy.  Promising materials systems will be integrated into prototype nanomechanical switches, and their functionality will be tested up to trillions of cycles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The motivation for this work is that nanoelectromechanical (NEMS) switches can offer 10 to 100 times lower power consumption than conventional solid state transistors, but a lack of knowledge of the phenomena controlling adhesion, electrical contact resistance (ECR) and the in-operando evolution of these properties, prevents their application. Our goal is to gain this missing fundamental knowledge and determine which materials and operating conditions minimize such evolution, thereby transforming integrated circuit (IC) technology to an energy-efficient technology. We strive to create a new validated interdisciplinary nanomechanics framework that provides understanding and enables technology thereby to overcome the tribo-, chemo-, and electro-mechanical degradation that occurs at NEMS switch contact interfaces.

The project consists of four closely integrated thrusts. The main outcomes for each are described next.  One of the main issues for NEMS switches is that to date, their size is thousands of times larger than today's transistors.  In the first thrust, we developed, fabricated and demonstrated a new switch topology that is scalable to the size of current devices.  A second major issue is the repeatability of such switches when they are subject to the enormous electrical fields they will experience at this scale.  In our second thrust, we showed that in spite of these fields, voltages are low enough that no extra damage occurs in addition to that due to mechanical contact only.  This place future focus on developing superhard materials that do not deform after repetitive cycling. A third issue is that the surfaces are subject to polymer formation, which can increase their electrical contact resistance. Using atomic force microscopy methods, we have measured the evolution of the polymer's volume over time, and developed a new validated mechanicstic model that describes its growth.  A fourth major issue is the need to develop contact materials other than metals, which are subject to high adhesion.  We have demonstrated by density functional theory modeling that metal phosphides are an excellent candidate for these contacting surfaces.
